alert.note: Alert for Lower Columbia Basin of Oregon (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pendleton (Northeast Oregon and Southeast Washington)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued July 23 at 9:39PM PDT until July 24 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton
info.description: ...WINDY CONDITIONS WITH LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE COLUMBIA BASIN MONDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING... .On Monday, a robust weather system will push a cold front through the forecast area and make for more widespread windy conditions, particularly in the Cascade Gaps and Columbia Basin. Sustained winds around 20 to 25 mph are possible in the Basin Monday afternoon and evening, with gusts as high as 35 mph possible. While RHs will improve through the day as temperatures drop, the windy conditions will still exacerbate concerns for fire initiation and spread. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM TO 11 PM PDT MONDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR WESTERN PORTIONS OF FIRE WEATHER ZONES OR641 AND WA691... ...RED FLAG WARNING WILL EXPIRE AT 10 PM PDT THIS EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR WESTERN PORTIONS OF FIRE WEATHER ZONES OR641 AND WA691... * AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 641 Lower Columbia Basin of Oregon and 691 Lower Columbia Basin. The Red Flag Warning for the western portion of these zones will expire at 10 PM PDT as RHs have risen to above critical fire levels. The Red Flag Warning for the entire Lower Columbia Basin remains in effect on Monday from 11 AM PDT to 11 PM PDT. * WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph on Monday. For the rest of tonight winds will continue to diminish to less than 10-15 kts. * RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 18 percent on Monday. For the rest of this evening, RHs will rise to 20-35 percent. * IMPACTS...Any existing fire or new fire starts will have the potential to spread rapidly given the windy conditions and low relative humidity on Monday.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
